Description: Scarab in glazed composition, probably mould-made; underside decorated with motif vertically arranged representing a seated griffin facing right, with three-pointed branch extending from its back.
Curator's comments: Scarab not yet located, published by Petrie (Petrie 1886, pl. XXXVIII, no. 21). It was discovered in the Scarab Factory (initial F indicated below Petrie's drawing). Lion, sphinx and griffin - sometimes winged - appear regularly on the scarabs produced at the “Scarab Factory” (on its various productions, see: Gorton 1996, 91-131; Webb forthcoming). This scarab belongs to a type which was widely distributed in the Mediterranean area and Southern Russia (Gorton 1996, 93, 95-96, type XXVIII A, subtype A177-183, especially A178 for this piece). Gorton, A.F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites, Oxford. Petrie, W.M.F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I, 1884–5 (Third Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Webb, V. forthcoming, Faience finds from Naukratis and their implications for the chronology of the site, in R. Thomas (ed.) forthcoming. Naukratis in Context I: The Nile Delta as a Landscape of Connectivity. Proceedings of the First Naukratis Project Workshop held at The British Museum 16th –17th December 2011.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (pl. XXXVII, no. 21)
Gorton 1996 / Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites (p. 99, Type XXVIII A178)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OC.028) (phase 3)
